awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Effects of Increased Freshwater Inputs and Salt Water Intrusion on the Current and Future Greenhouse Carbon Balance of Everglade Wetlands
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a renewal project to study carbon balance in the Florida everglades and the interactive effects of climate change, hydrology, and saltwater intrusion. This effort supports continued atmospheric observations of carbon dioxide and methane concentrations, and water and energy fluxes at 2 sites in the freshwater marsh regions of Everglades National Park. The collection of data from 2 additional sites will allow the science investigators to scale up to a regional level and to better develop predictive models to estimate future ecosystem greenhouse carbon balance in the Everglades.

The four study sites are co-located with Florida Coastal Everglades Long Term Ecological Research (FCE-LTER) sites and represent the strong gradients found in marsh and mangrove ecosystems of the Park. This work will also contribute to research being conducted through the NSF-supported National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) Program, the National Park Service, the South Florida Water Management District (SFWMD), and the United States Geological Survey (USGS).

por.por_cntn:
This project asked: how much methane is currently released from Everglades wetlands, what factors control methane production, and what is the balance of the two greenhouse gases, carbon dioxide (CO2) and methane (natural gas, CH4), coming from the Everglades?

CH4 is a stronger greenhouse gas per molecule than CO2, although CH4 concentrations are far lower than those of CO2, which persists in the atmosphere much longer than CH4. Atmospheric CH4 comes from natural and human derived sources. Most natural CH4 production comes from flooded wetlands, where water blocks diffusion of oxygen into soil pore spaces and microbes that consume oxygen and release CO2 during decomposition are unable to thrive. Instead, decomposers that break down soil organic matter without oxygen —but release CH4— prosper. While wetlands are the single largest source of CH4 in air, all human-driven sources combined are greater than CH4 released from wetlands. Human-derived CH4 sources include rice paddies, fires, landfills, livestock production, artificial reservoirs, and natural gas, oil, and coal extraction, transport, and burning.

The subtropical Everglades are among the largest wetlands in North America, with plants and microorganisms active year-round, suggesting the Everglades might be a significant source of CH4. Historically, the Everglades were a sink for CO2 indicated by the presence of deep peat soils. The Everglades are currently highly modified with water inputs controlled by water management and rainfall. The current Everglades restoration plan aims to increase water flow into Everglades National Park (ENP).

We measured the exchange of CO2 and CH4 with the atmosphere at three sites in the Everglades, combining short-term spot measurements of different vegetation types with whole ecosystem measurements for annual estimates for larger areas. Two sites are freshwater marsh in ENP, one in Shark River Slough, usually inundated year-round, and one in north Taylor Slough, inundated from mid wet season to early dry season (June – January). In January 2020, we initiated measurements at a third site in the Southeast Everglades to evaluate effects of increased salinity on greenhouse gas exchange at an Everglades marsh experiencing sea level rise.

When we started in 2007, whether Everglade wetlands were presently sources or sinks for CO2 was unknown. Our data indicated that the freshwater sites are near equilibrium, neither storing nor releasing much CO2. With new data from this project, we show that the CO2 balance changes with climate and weather patterns that differ each year, such as high rainfall during an El Niño Southern Oscillation events. Long periods of high water negatively affect plant and ecosystem productivity at the Taylor Slough site, which became a source of CO2. Increased water levels there are causing expansion of wetland species tolerant of flooding at the expense of species active during the dry season. In both field data and a lab experiment we found that the combined effects of water depth and flooding duration on plant health are not simply additive.

To estimate aquatic productivity (underwater photosynthesis), we deployed dissolved oxygen sensors within the water column. While emergent plants (plants with leaves above water) dominate total system productivity, aquatic productivity sometimes can account for a large part of total ecosystem photosynthesis.

Both freshwater wetlands marshes are sources of CH4 on average, though Shark River releases more than the intermittently dry Taylor Slough site. Within Shark River the vegetation takes two forms, ridges composed of dense stands of sawgrass, and sloughs which are mostly open water sparsely vegetated by water lilies and short rushes. Much of CH4 release from flooded soils is known to move through wetland plants in tissue used to transport oxygen to roots for aerobic metabolism, and our studies support that observation. Ridges almost always have higher CH4 release than sloughs. We used our data from the two freshwater marsh sites, which have similar climate but different hydrology, to develop and test protocols and recommendations for analysis of CH4 ecosystem exchange data. We found that the primary factors affecting CH4 release were air temperature, water level, and recent ecosystem photosynthesis.

Our new site in Southeast Everglades has experienced a rapid die-off of sawgrass and expansion of red mangrove in the past three years because of increases in salinity above the tolerance of sawgrass and increases in phosphorus accompanying the salt water.  The site is releasing some CH4, but CO2 uptake is very high and increasing rapidly, doubling from 2020 to 2021 and much higher than that of the marshes because of expansion of red mangrove. 

This project has launched the careers of one early career faculty member of an underrepresented group, two postdocs and two graduate students. The project also has exposed over 500 students in our courses to the Everglades and our research.  Our data have been downloaded more than 2500 times during the project period and is currently being used by Everglades National Park for their modeling and planning.
